Notes on notation

notation.Rmd

The purpose of this short vignette is to document the notation conventions for the math and programming related to PLMM. We begin with the math, and then translate our math notation into naming objects in our source code.

Throughout this document, the reader will notice some notation conventions:

  • Matrices are denoted with boldface, UPPERCASE letters
  • Vectors are denoted with boldface lowercase letters
  • Scalar values and indices are denoted with lowercase letters
  • the Ì‡\dot{} modifier indicates (column) standardization
  • the Ìƒ\tilde{} modifier indicates rotation

Math notation

Here are the concepts we need to denote, in order of their usage in our derivations. I have blocked these into sections corresponding to the steps of the model fitting process.

Statistical model (the overall framework)

The overall model can be written as

ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ™ğ›„+ğ›œ \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \mathbf{Z}\boldsymbol{\gamma} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}

or equivalently as ğ²=ğ—Ì‡ğ›ƒÌ‡+ğ®+ğ›œ \mathbf{y} = \dot{\mathbf{X}}\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}} + \mathbf{u} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} where:

  • ğ—\mathbf{X} and ğ²\mathbf{y} are the nÃ—pn \times p design matrix of our data and the nÃ—1n \times 1 vector of outcomes, respectively. Here, nn is the number of observations (e.g., number of patients, number of samples, etc.) and pp is the number of features (e.g., number of SNPs, number of variables, number of covariates, etc.).

  • ğ—Ì‡\dot{\mathbf{X}} is the column-standardized ğ—\mathbf{X}, in which each of the pp columns has mean 0 and standard deviation 1. Note: ğ—Ì‡\dot{\mathbf{X}} excludes any singular features (columns of constants) in the original ğ—\mathbf{X}.

  • ğ›ƒÌ‡\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}} represents the coefficients on the standardized scale.

  • ğ™\mathbf{Z} is a nÃ—bn \times b matrix of indicators corresponding to a grouping structure, and ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma} is the vector of values describing how each grouping is associated with ğ²\mathbf{y}. In real data, these values typically unknown.

  • ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} is the nÃ—1n \times 1 vector of noise.

We define the realized (or empirical) relatedness matrix as ğŠâ‰¡1pğ—Ì‡ğ—Ì‡âŠ¤\mathbf{K} \equiv \frac{1}{p}\dot{\mathbf{X}}\dot{\mathbf{X}}^\top

This model assumes:

  • ğ›œâŠ¥ğ®\boldsymbol{\epsilon} \perp \mathbf{u}
  • ğ›œâˆ¼N(0,ÏƒÏµ2ğˆ)\boldsymbol{\epsilon} \sim N(0, \sigma^2_{\epsilon}\mathbf{I})
  • ğ®âˆ¼N(0,Ïƒs2ğŠ)\mathbf{u} \sim N(0, \sigma^2_{s}\mathbf{K})

Under these assumptions, we may write ğ²âˆ¼N(ğ—Ì‡ğ›ƒÌ‡,ğšº)\mathbf{y} \sim N(\dot{\mathbf{X}}\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})

Indices:

  • iâˆˆ1,...,ni \in 1,..., n indexes observations
  • jâˆˆ1,...,pj \in 1,..., p indexes features
  • hâˆˆ1,...,bh \in 1,..., b indexes the batches (e.g., different family groups, different data collection sites, etc.)

Decomposition and rotation (prep and first part of fit)

  • Beginning with an eigendecomposition, we have ğ”\mathbf{U} and ğ¬\mathbf{s} are the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of ğŠ\mathbf{K}, as one would obtain from eigen(ğŠ)â‰¡ğ”ğ’ğ”âŠ¤\text{eigen}(\mathbf{K)} \equiv \mathbf{U}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{U}^\top. The elements of ğ¬\mathbf{s} are the diagonal values of ğ’\mathbf{S}. Note, random effect ğ®\mathbf{u} is distinct from the columns of matrix ğ”\mathbf{U}.

  • kk represents the number of nonzero eigenvalues represented in ğ”\mathbf{U} and ğ\mathbf{d}, so kâ‰¤min(n,p)k \leq \text{min}(n,p).

  • Again, ğŠâ‰¡1pğ—Ì‡ğ—Ì‡âŠ¤\mathbf{K} \equiv \frac{1}{p}\dot{\mathbf{X}}\dot{\mathbf{X}}^{\top} is often referred to in the literature as the realized relatedness matrix (RRM) or genomic relatedness matrix (GRM). ğŠ\mathbf{K} has dimension nÃ—nn \times n.

  • Î·\eta is the ratio Ïƒs2Ïƒe2+Ïƒs2\frac{\sigma^2_s}{\sigma^2_e + \sigma^2_s}. We estimate Î·Ì‚\hat{\eta} from a null model (more details to come).

  • ğšº\mathbf{\Sigma} is the variance of the outcome, where ğ•(ğ²)=Î·ğŠ+(1âˆ’Î·)ğˆn\mathbb{V}({\mathbf{y}}) = \eta \mathbf{K} + (1 - \eta)\mathbf{I}_n.

  • ğ°\mathbf{w} is the vector of weights defined as (Î·ğ¬+(1âˆ’Î·))âˆ’1/2(\eta\mathbf{\mathbf{s}} + (1-\eta))^{-1/2}. The values in ğ°\mathbf{w} are the nonzero values of the diagonal matrix ğ–â‰¡(Î·ğ’+(1âˆ’Î·)ğˆ)âˆ’1/2\mathbf{W} \equiv (\eta\mathbf{S} + (1 - \eta)\mathbf{I})^{-1/2}.

  • The matrix to be used in rotating (or preconditioning) the data is ğšºâˆ’1/2â‰¡ğ–ğ”âŠ¤\mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \equiv \mathbf{W}\mathbf{U}^\top.

  • ğ—Ì‡Ìƒâ‰¡ğ–ğ”âŠ¤ğ—Ì‡\tilde{\dot{\mathbf{X}}} \equiv \mathbf{W}\mathbf{U}^\top\dot{\mathbf{X}} is the rotated data, or the data on the transformed scale.

  • ğ²Ìƒâ‰¡ğšºâˆ’1/2ğ²\tilde{\mathbf{y}} \equiv \mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\mathbf{y} is the outcome on the rotated scale.

  • ğ—ÌƒÌˆ\ddot{\tilde{\mathbf{X}}} is the standardized rotated data. Note: This standardization involves scaling, but not centering. This post-rotation standardization impacts the estimated coefficients as well; we define ğ›ƒÌˆ{\ddot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} as the estimated coefficients on this scale.

Model fitting with penalization

We fit ğ²Ìƒâˆ¼ğ—ÌƒÌˆ\tilde{\mathbf{y}} \sim \ddot{\tilde{\mathbf{X}}} using a penalized linear mixed model, and obtain ğ›ƒÌˆÌ‚\hat{\ddot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} as our estimated coefficients. The penalty parameter values (e.g., values of the lasso tuning parameter) are indexed by Î»lâˆˆ1,...,t\lambda_l \in 1,..., t.

Rescaling results (format)

To obtain the estimated coefficients on the original scale, the values estimated by the model must be unscaled (or â€˜untransformedâ€™) twice: once to adjust for the post-rotation standardization, and again to adjust for the pre-rotation standardization. This process could be written ğ›ƒÌˆÌ‚â†’ğ›ƒÌ‡Ì‚â†’ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\ddot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} \rightarrow \hat{\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} \rightarrow \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}.

Object names in source code

In the code, we denote the objects above in this way:

  • ğ—\mathbf{X} and ğ²\mathbf{y} are X and y

  • ğ—Ì‡\dot{\mathbf{X}} is std_X

  • ğ—Ì‡Ìƒ\tilde{\dot{\mathbf{X}}} is rot_X

  • ğ—ÌƒÌˆ\ddot{\tilde{\mathbf{X}}} is stdrot_X

  • ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} is named og_scale_beta in helper functions (for clarity) and returned in plmm objects as beta_vals. beta_vals and og_scale_beta are equivalent; both represent the estimated coefficients on the original scale.

  • ğ›ƒÌ‡Ì‚\hat{\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} is std_scale_beta

  • ğ›ƒÌˆÌ‚\hat{\ddot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} is stdrot_scale_beta

  • ğ—Ì‡ğ›ƒÌ‡Ì‚\dot{\mathbf{X}}\hat{\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} is Xb

  • ğ—ÌƒÌˆğ›ƒÌˆÌ‚\ddot{\tilde{\mathbf{X}}} \hat{\ddot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}} is linear_predictors. Note: in words, this means the linear_predictors in the code are on the scale of the rotated and re-standardized data!

  • ğšºÌ‚â‰¡Î·Ì‚ğŠ+(1âˆ’Î·Ì‚)ğˆ\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} \equiv \hat{\eta}\mathbf{K} + (1 - \hat{\eta})\mathbf{I} is estimated_Sigma. Similarly, ğšºÌ‚11\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{11} is Sigma_11, etc.
